Volcanic outgassing of CO2 and H2O on Mars
M. Grott ⁎, A. Morschhauser, D. Breuer, E. Hauber Institute of Planetary Research, German Aerospace Center (DLR), Rutherfordstraße 2, 12489 Berlin, Germany

Editor: Y. Ricard
Keywords: Mars volcanism outgassing CO2 water geophysics
Volcanic outgassing is one of the main sources of volatiles for the martian atmosphere and degassing of the martian interior potentially influenced the early martian climate. Using a parameterized thermo-chemical evolutionmodel and considering two end-membermeltingmodels, we self-consistently calculate the amount of CO2 and H2O outgassed during themartian evolution. Outgassing rates are found to depend primarily on a factor describing the outgassing efficiency, the bulk mantle water content, the mantle oxygen fugacity, and the local melt fraction in the magma source regions. We find that significant outgassing ceased around 3.5–2 Gyr ago, depending on the adoptedmeltingmodel. A total of 0.9–1 bar CO2 is outgassed during this timeperiod if amantle oxygen fugacity corresponding to one log10 unit above the iron–wustite buffer is assumed. Additionally, a total of 17–61 mofwater is delivered to the surface. Outgassing ismost efficient in the pre-Noachian (up to 4.1 Gyr), but still significant during the Noachian, and 5–15 m of water and ∼250 mbar of CO2 are outgassed between 4.1 and 3.7 Gyr.Although this amount isprobably insufficient for anappreciable greenhouse effect, pressures are found to be sufficient to stabilize transient liquidwateron the surfacewell into theHesperianperiod. Therefore, our results support the hypothesis that rather than being warm-and-wet, the martian climate was probably cold-and-wet. Outgassing is found to strongly decline during the Hesperian, and is insignificant during the Amazonian period. A simple parameterization for the outgassing of CO2 and H2O as a function of time is presented.

sections.heading: 1.1. Martian atmospheric evolution
sections.text:
The question of if and when the martian atmosphere was dense enough to allow liquid water to be stable on the planetary surface has attracted considerable attention and atmospheric conditions sensitively influence the habitability of the planet. Following accretion and core formation, Mars was likely covered by a global magma ocean, and an appreciable H2O−CO2 atmosphere probably built up during this time period. Estimates of the density of the primordial atmosphere range from 1 to 100 bar (Elkins-Tanton, 2008; Hirschmann and Withers, 2008), and the atmosphere was probably thick enough to significantly reduce magma ocean cooling (Elkins-Tanton, 2008).
During the early history of the solar system the extreme ultraviolet (EUV) flux from the young sun is believed to have been much larger than it is today and, as a consequence, atmospheric temperatures are assumed to have been significantly increased. This would have resulted in an expansion of the atmosphere, leading to efficient atmospheric loss through thermal escape of heavy, neutral particles. Models indicate that an early CO2-dominated atmosphere could not have been maintained (Tian et al., 2009), and atmospheric loss rates
could have been as large as 0.1–1 bar per Myr before 4.1 Gyr. In addition to thermal escape, atmosphere could have been lost through impact erosion (Melosh and Vickery, 1989; Pham et al., 2009), such that the primordial atmosphere was likely entirely eroded.
During the Noachian period between 4.1 and 3.7 Gyr b.p., atmospheric pressure was determined by the interplay between volcanic outgassing, impact erosion/delivery, CO2 adsorption to the regolith, CO2 storage in the polar caps, and CO2 sequestration in carbonate rocks (e.g., Jakosky and Phillips, 2001; Manning et al., 2006). Furthermore, loss processes like sputtering, dissociative recombination, and ion escape became efficient, and although the timing of the dynamo shutdown is still controversial, it is generally assumed tohaveoccurred at around the same time, and could have potentially resulted in enhanced atmospheric loss. Atmospheric pressures and temperatures during the Noachian have been extensively modeled and it was found that atmospheric conditions allowing for liquid water to be stable on the surface are difficult to achieve. For a CO2-dominated atmosphere, climate models require surface pressures of several bar CO2 to obtain surface temperatures above freezing (Kasting, 1991), although this value can be reduced to 0.5–1 bar if scattering of infrared radiation from CO2 ice clouds is taken into account (Forget and Pierrehumbert, 1997).
Alternative models to account for warmer surface temperatures include additional greenhouse gasses likeCH4, SO2 andH2S,which could have been released by volcanism. While the release of CH4 is probably not sufficient to account for appreciable greenhouse warming (Kasting, 1997), sulfur is highly soluble in martian basalts (Johnson et al., 2008),
and sulfur volatiles could therefore add significantly to an earlymartian greenhouse.Due to their short lifetimes, greenhousewarmingcausedby SO2 and H2S would only be efficient as long as these species are continuously supplied to the atmosphere, but they could causewarming by up to 25 K (Johnson et al., 2008). Furthermore, aqueous solutions with lower melting points have been extensively studied (see, e.g., Fairén (2010) and references therein) and instead of being warm-andwet (Jakosky and Phillips, 2001),Marsmight have been cold-and-wet in the sense that average surface temperatureswere around 245 K (Fairén, 2010; Gaidos and Marion, 2003).
When outgassing and impact delivery of volatiles waned around the beginning of the Hesperian, loss processes prevailed and the D/H ratio in the martian atmosphere indicates that 60–90% of the martian water inventory has been lost to space (Jakosky and Phillips, 2001). The amount of atmospheric CO2 lost in the last 3.5 Gyr is still under debate, but most estimates are of the order of tens to a few hundred millibars (Johnson et al., 2000; Lammer et al., 2008; Luhmann et al., 1992) rather than a substantial fraction of a bar, giving further support to the cold-and-wet Mars hypothesis. Note, however, that carbonates have been detected on the surface of Mars (Ehlmann et al., 2008; Michalski and Niles, 2010), and it has been suggested that carbonate minerals equivalent to 1 bar of CO2 could have been deposited (Griffith and Shock, 1995). This would correspond to a global carbonate layer of 20 m thickness (Warren, 1987), but the total amount of CO2 sequestered in crustal rocks remains unknown.

sections.heading: 1.2. Surface geological record
sections.text:
Several lines of evidence suggest that liquid water was once a geological agent at and near the surface of Mars (Baker, 2001), but the exact timing and duration of water-related events are a matter of ongoingdebate.Nevertheless, there is a consensus that liquidwaterwas planet-wide available in the early history ofMars, although in unknown quantities. Later, the surface became more and more dry, until the environment approached the hyperarid conditions that prevail today.
Widespread fluvial valley networks in ancient cratered terrain were carved by surface runoff, but it is not entirely clear if the water was supplied by precipitation (rain or snow) (Craddock and Howard, 2002) or by groundwater seepage (Goldspiel and Squyres, 2000).Seepage alone as valley-forming process is considered unlikely, however, because some valleys have their origins at the crest of hills, which would not be expected if they were formed by seepage induced by hydrothermal activity (e.g., Mangold et al., 2004). Moreover, terrestrial experience shows that flash floods are required to remove the debris generated by seepageweathering (Irwin et al., 2008; Lamb et al., 2008). In any case the Noachian was characterized by an active hydrological cycle, because sapping also requires precipitation to recharge the groundwater system. Overall, however, the fluvial morphology of the Noachian landscape is poorly developed and suggests an arid climate (Barnhart et al., 2009; Irwin et al., 2011; Stepinski and Coradetti, 2004; Stepinski and Stepinski, 2005). Valley network formation occurred over an extended period of time, but in varying intensity and of perhaps ephemeral nature, and might have ended with an intense period of fluvial dissection (Howard et al., 2005; Irwin et al., 2005) between the endof theNoachianand thebeginningof theHesperianat∼3.8 to 3.5 Ga (Fassett and Head, 2008a).
The Noachian would also have been the most likely time during which an ocean in the northern lowlands acted as a natural global sink for water (Clifford and Parker, 2001), though unambiguous morphologic or compositional evidence for such a global ocean is still lacking (review by Carr and Head, 2003). Nevertheless, deltaic intra-crater sediments (e.g., Hauber et al., 2009) and craters with fluvial inlets and outlets (Fassett and Head, 2008b) indicate smaller-than-ocean-sized (though still substantial) standing bodies of water in the Noachian, but there is no consensus on their longevity.Most of the sedimentary bodies might have formed at very short timescales (e.g., Kleinhans et al., 2010)
and may not require an exceptionally warm and wet climate. Unambiguous evidence for liquid water comes from the orbital discovery of widespread phyllosilicates (Mustard et al., 2008; Poulet et al., 2005) in ancient cratered terrain, products of the aqueous alteration of basaltic parent materials under neutral pH conditions.
The transition from the Noachian to the Hesperian is marked by a sharp decline in erosion rates (Craddock andMaxwell, 1993; Golombek et al., 2006). Fluvial processes were still active (Mangold et al., 2004), but the number of newly formed valley networks decreases and their morphology suggests that sapping became the predominant agent of erosion (Harrison and Grimm, 2005). The transition to a groundwaterdominated hydrology is also indicated by the characteristics of stratified sediments in Meridiani Planum, which is best explained by episodic wetting through upwelling surface water (Grotzinger et al., 2005) controlled by a fluctuating water table (Andrews-Hanna et al., 2010). While some lakes and associateddeltaic deposits are dated asHesperian (Di Achille et al., 2007;Malin and Edgett, 2003), local factorsmight have contributed to their formation and it is questionable if their existence reflects climatic conditions that were significantly different from today.
Other geological observations are also consistent with a thin Hesperian atmosphere, and olivine outcrops, which would weather rapidly in the presence of water (Hoefen et al., 2003) lend additional support for a generally dry Hesperian climate. A perhaps even more important mineralogical indication of a changing environment is the distribution of hydrated minerals, with more abundant outcrops found in Noachian terrains and less evidence for hydration observed in younger regions (e.g., Bibring et al., 2006; Murchie et al., 2009). While some of the observed phyllosilicates and carbonates in Noachian terrains might have formed in aqueous environments with neutral or alkaline pH (e.g., Murchie et al., 2009), sulfate-bearing Hesperian units might have experiencedmuchdrier and acidic conditions (e.g., Altheide et al., 2009; Berger et al., 2009). The abrupt beginnings of Hesperianaged outflow channels clearly indicate that they were not fed by precipitation, but by some mechanism that released water from the subsurface, perhaps by melting or cracking the thickening cryosphere (Clifford, 1993). Although the amount of surface water implied by the huge channel dimensions is large, such processes do not require a thick atmosphere.
The Amazonian is characterized by very cold and hyperarid conditions and evidence for liquid water is even sparser than in the Hesperian. Late Hesperian to Early Amazonian mid-latitude valleys (Dickson et al., 2009) were probably formed by meltwater from snow and/or ice deposits, and fluvial and debris flow processes carved gullies (Malin and Edgett, 2000), which are very young (∼105 to 106 years; Reiss et al., 2004). Their origin involved liquid water and might be related to recent changes in the orbital configuration of the planet.
In summary, the geological record displays a gradual decrease in the amount of liquidwater at or near the surface and the poor development of fluvial features indicates that most of the Noachian probably never experienced awarmandwet climate similar to that of the current Earth. Towards the Hesperian, the global hydrology became groundwaterdominated (Andrews-Hanna and Lewis, 2011), surface water became episodic and short-lived, the groundwater table sank with time (Reiss et al., 2006), andMars turned into the cold desert planet that it is today. Major uncertainties exist with respect to the total amount of water present at the surface during the different epochs, and the related evolution of atmospheric density. Nevertheless, it appears likely that water in the Hesperian and Amazonian was transient and related to local and regional factors, and consequently no dense atmosphere would be required.

sections.heading: 1.3. Volcanic outgassing
sections.text:
Together with impact delivery (Pham et al., 2009) and the reactivation of subsurface reservoirs, volcanic outgassing is one of the main sources of volatiles for the martian atmosphere (Jakosky and
Phillips, 2001; Phillips et al., 2001), and several attempts have been made to quantify the timing and amount of gasses released through volcanism. To determine the rate of magma production, most models rely on estimates based on the surface geological record (Craddock and Greeley, 2009;Hirschmann andWithers, 2008; Phillips et al., 2001), and an equivalent amount of a 5 km thick global crustal layer is assumed to have been produced since 3.8 Gyr by extrusive and intrusive volcanism (Greeley and Schneid, 1991). The timing of crustal production is also usually deduced from the surface record, but somemodels scalemagma production rates with planetary heat flow (Manning et al., 2006), assuming that some fraction of the heat is transported to the surface by volcanic heat piping.
To arrive at expressions for atmospheric densities, most outgassing models assume afixedmagmavolatile content,which is thenmultiplied by the crust production rate to estimate the release rate of volcanic gasses as a function of time. In analogy with the Earth, volatile contents of the order of 0.65 wt.% are usually assumed (Craddock and Greeley, 2009; O'Neill et al., 2007; Phillips et al., 2001), consistent with CO2 abundances in Hawaiian basalts. In this manner, large atmospheric pressures of the order of 1.5 bar are obtained for the outgassing associatedwith the formation of Tharsis alone (Phillips et al., 2001), and it has been argued that volcanic outgassing could have significantly influenced the late Noachian to early Hesperian climate.
Using a chemical model for the solubility of CO2 in martian basalt under graphite saturated conditions, Hirschmann and Withers (2008) and Stanley et al., submitted for publication have reinvestigated the CO2 content of martian magmas and found that—apart from the pressure and temperature conditions in the magma source region—CO2 content primarily depends on oxygen fugacity. For a plausible range of P–Tconditions, Hirschmann andWithers (2008) estimated that CO2 content in martian magmas is only 0.01–0.1 wt.% CO2, such that magmatic CO2 content has probably been overestimated in previous models. This significantly reduces the amount of CO2 released to the atmosphere and Hirschmann andWithers (2008) estimate that only 0.1 to at most 1 bar of CO2 were outgassed after 3.8 Gyr.
Here we combine a parameterized thermo-chemical evolution model (Morschhauser et al., 2011) with a model for the solubility of CO2 in basaltic melt (Hirschmann and Withers, 2008) to selfconsistently calculate the dissolved amount of CO2 and H2O in martian magmas. Magma water content is calculated using a fractional melting model, while simultaneously considering the maximum water solubility. Outgassing of CO2 and H2O is then tracked as a function of time and in thisway the timingandamountofoutgassing canbecalculated taking the pressure and temperature conditions in the magma source region self-consistently into account. Finally, we will present a parameterization for volcanic outgassing which accounts for outgassing efficiency, oxygen fugacity, as well as the initial mantle water content.

sections.heading: 2. Modeling
sections.text: To calculate the amount of outgassed CO2 and H2O, the thermochemical evolution of Mars is modeled using one dimensional, parameterized convection models. Being in the stagnant lid mode of mantle convection, temperatures in the martian interior are determined by the energy balance in the core, mantle, and stagnant lid, and heat flows at the core–mantle boundary and the lithospheric base are calculated using scaling laws for stagnant lid convection (Grasset and Parmentier, 1998). Starting from an initial temperature profile corresponding to the time after core formation, temperatures are calculated using the model by (Morschhauser et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 2.1. Magmatic evolution
sections.text:
Partial mantle melting and crustal production are calculated selfconsistently by comparing the mantle temperature profile to the solidus temperature of mantle rocks and we follow an approach
similar to that of Breuer and Spohn (2006), but take the solidus increase upon depletion of crustal components into account. As in the model by Morschhauser et al. (2011), extraction of heat producing elements from the mantle and accumulation of these elements in the crust is calculated self-consistently. Dehydration stiffening of the mantle viscosity is taken into account using the formulation by Fraeman and Korenaga (2010), and volcanic heat-piping is accounted for when calculating lithospheric growth and solving the energy balance equation at the lithospheric base.
The solidus of the martian mantle is parameterized using the phase relations for terrestrial peridotite byTakahashi (1990),which is similar to other parameterizations of the peridotite solidus (see, e.g.,Morschhauser et al., 2011) and covers the entire pressure range between 0 and 10 GPa. Although the martian mantle is probably much more iron rich than that of the Earth, melting experiments suggest that Mg# has only a minor influence on the peridotite solidus (Hirschmann, 2000), such that adopting the terrestrial parameterization seems justified.
Given the local temperature T, the local melt fraction F is calculated assuming a linear increase of melt fraction with temperature and the melt fraction is given by

Due to the higher compressibility of basaltic melt with respect to mantle rock, melt loses its buoyancy at pressures around 6 GPa (Suzuki et al., 1998) and we will only consider meltzones shallower than this depth in the following.
Once the available amount ofmelt has been calculated, the change of crustal thickness Dcr can be calculated if a uniform distribution of extracted melt onto the planetary surface is assumed. If mantle dynamics is dominated by large, spread-out upwellings, melting will occur over a large fraction of individual convection cells and fp will be close to unity. If, however, mantle dynamics is dominated by localized mantle plumes, melting will be restricted to relatively small areas (e.g., Li and Kiefer, 2007) and fp will be much smaller than one. Here we will consider two end-member cases corresponding to melting in a global melt channel with fp=1, and melting restricted to mantle plumes with fp=0.01. If the case of a global melt channel is considered, the local temperature T is given by the lithospheric and mantle temperature profiles, depending on depth. sections.heading: 2.3. Outgassing of CO2
sections.text:
The redox state of the martian mantle can be constrained from geochemical analysis of the SNCmeteorites (Herd et al., 2002; Shearer et al., 2006) and results indicate that oxygen fugacities for martian basalts span about four orders of magnitude, ranging from the iron–wustite (IW) to the quartz–fayalite–magnetite (QFM) buffers. Of these meteorites, the shergottites are the petrologically most primitive and are likely to reflect the redox state of themantle. Shergottites are on the reduced end of the above range and typically have oxygen fugacities around IW or one log10 unit above (IW+1) (Herd, 2003; Herd et al., 2002; Karner et al., 2007; Shearer et al., 2006). Furthermore, trace elementanalysis of theoldestmartianmeteorite ALH84001,whichhas a crystallization age of 4.1 Gyr (Lapen et al., 2010), indicates even more reducing conditions around IW-1 (Warren and Kallmeyen, 1996). This implies that the early martian mantle could have been more reducing than the source regions sampled by the younger martian meteorites, and an oxidation state between one log10 unit above and below the IW buffer is usually assumed for the martian mantle.
At these relatively reducing conditions andpressures encountered in the source regions ofmartian basalts, carbonwill be stable in the formof graphite. During partialmelting of themantle, some of this graphitewill dissolve in the form of carbonate ions and the dissolved carbonate can subsequently be outgassed in the form of CO2 at shallow depths. To calculate the amount of CO2 dissolved in the melt, we follow the approach developed by (Holloway et al., 1992) and (Holloway, 1998), who consider the solubility of CO2 in graphite-saturated magmas.
The abundance of carbonate in the melt is determined from a reaction of CO2 in the vapor phasewith oxygen, and is directly related to the fugacity of CO2. In turn, CO2 is produced fromgraphite andmolecular oxygen, and the CO2 abundance therefore depends on oxygen fugacity. In graphite-saturated systems, the concentration of carbonate in the melt XCO32− melt may therefore be expressed as
XmeltCO2−3 = KIIKIfO2
1 + KIIKIfO2 ð13Þ
where KI is the equilibrium constant governing the reaction of forming CO2 from graphite, KII is the equilibrium constant for the reaction of forming CO32− from CO2, and fO2 is the oxygen fugacity (Hirschmann and Withers, 2008).
The equilibrium constants KI and KII are pressure and temperature dependent and KI has been determined for mid ocean ridge basalt (MORB) and Hawaiian basalts. KII was experimentally determined for MORB and a prescription for calculating KI and KII may be found in (Holloway et al., 1992). Although it would be preferable to use calibrations of KI and KII for martian basalts, this data is currently missing. Following Hirschmann andWithers (2008), wewill therefore assume that the pressure and temperature dependence of KI and KII are applicable when considering the carbonate concentration in graphite-saturated melts on Mars.
The concentration of CO2 in the melt can be calculated from the abundance of carbonate XCO32−

An oxygen fugacity corresponding to IW has been assumed and solubility increases with increasing melt fraction, i.e., temperature. In order to calculate the amount of CO2 released to the atmosphere, the depth dependent concentration of CO2 given in Eq. (14) is averaged over the meltzone and

The mass of CO2 removed from the mantle is then proportional to the crust formation rate and can be calculated from

In order to outgas efficiently, CO2 bubbles need to nucleate in the magma and this process can commence as soon as CO2 becomes supersaturated in themelt. In rapidly ascendingmagma, graphitewill become undersaturated and CO2 solubility will no longer be determined by the redox state, but be governed by an equilibriumwith CO2 vapor instead. In this regime, CO2 solubility decreases with decreasing pressure (Hirschmann and Withers, 2008; Pan et al., 1991) and experimental data on tholeiitic basalts indicates that CO2 solubility becomes largely independent of temperature (Panet al., 1991). CO2 solubility is expected to be in the 10 ppm range at ambient pressures (Pan et al., 1991) and most CO2 is expected to outgas if themagma is erupted onto the surface.
If the undersaturatedmagma crystallizes in the form of plutons, CO2 will be enriched in the remaining liquid and eventually outgas. Herewe will assume that CO2 will reach the surface and contribute to the pressure of themartian atmosphere if somecrustal porosity is present at the depth of the intrusion, although in reality some of the CO2may react with the host rocks to formmetamorphicmineral phases. This approach is intermediate between those of Hirschmann and Withers (2008) and O'Neill et al. (2007), who assume that all and none of the intrusively
cooling magma adds to atmospheric outgassing, respectively. The CO2 partial pressure can then to first order be calculated according to

sections.heading: 2.4. Parameters
sections.text:
Parameters for the applied thermal evolution models are chosen in accordance with the successful models of (Morschhauser et al., 2011) and satisfy the following observational constraints: 1) Models do not show episodes of crustal recycling, as this would be incompatible with an early separation of geochemical reservoirs. 2)Models are compatible with the inferred crust formation history, and most of the crust is produced within the first 500 Myr of the planetary evolution. 3) The formation of partial melt should be possible under present-day mantle conditions, as documented by recent volcanic activity predominantly in the Tharsis province.
As determined by (Morschhauser et al., 2011), initial upper mantle temperatures should be relatively cool and we choose Tm=1620 and 1650 K for fp=1 and 0.01, respectively. Furthermore, the core is chosen to be super-heated by 300 K with respect to the mantle. This choice is motivated by the fact that a super-heated core is—apart from an early episode of plate tectonics (Breuer and Spohn, 2003)—one viable mechanism to drive a thermal dynamo early in martian history. In the presented models, a thermal dynamo could potentially operate for 650 Myr, while choosing a temperature excess of only 150 K would reduce the lifetime of the dynamo to 425 Myr.
The adopted reference viscosity of 1019 Pa s corresponds to a wet olivine mantle rheology (Karato and Wu, 1993), which is best compatible with the low elastic thicknesses determined for Noachian terrains (Grott and Breuer, 2008, 2010). Extraction of heat producing elements is calculated self-consistently, andwe use a single partitioning coefficient for K, Th, and U of Di=0.002 (see Fraeman and Korenaga, 2010 and references therein). For the bulk abundance of heat producing elements, we use the compositional model by Wänke and Dreibus (1994), which closely matches the observed K/Th ratio on the martian surface (Taylor et al., 2006). Outgassing from the formation of the primordial crust is not considered and we start our models with an initial crustal thickness of Dcr, 0=30 km, as indicated by geochemical analysis of martian meteorites (Norman, 1999).
It is usually assumed that only moderate amounts of water are present in the martian mantle and the compositional model by Wänke and Dreibus (1994) estimates the bulk water content to be 36 ppm. However, geochemical analysis of the martian meteorites suggests that the water content of the parent magmas might have been as high as 1.8 wt.% (McSween et al., 2001). Depending on the melt fraction, this could imply significantly higher mantle water contents. Trace element concentrations indicate that the melt fraction in the basalt source regions was between 2 and 10% in the shergottites (Borg and Draper, 2003; Norman, 1999), such that locally mantle water contents of 500 to 2000 ppm H2O seem possible. Furthermore support for a larger mantle bulk water content is provided by an analysis of hydrous amphibole in the Chassignymeteorite, which suggests bulk mantle water contents of 140–250 ppm (McCubbin et al., 2010). As no consensus on the mantle water concentration has been reached so far, we will assume a mantle water content of 100 ppm in the following. Note, however, that as long as the water saturation concentration is not exceeded in Eq. (8), mantle water content is a linear factor in Eq. (12). Therefore, the influence of different initial bulk mantle water contents is easily calculated. Other parameters used in the modeling are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
The two end-member cases of crustal production considered in this study represent melting in a global melt channel as well as melting restricted to a small fraction of the planetary surface corresponding to hot mantle upwellings. Initial upper mantle temperatures for these two cases have been chosen such that both models result in identical present-day crustal thicknesses, facilitating a comparison between the outgassing histories associated with these models. Both models have present-day crustal thicknesses of 54 km.
Fig. 3 shows the thickness of the crust (dashed line), the stagnant lid thickness (solid line) aswell as the extent of themeltzone for the case of a global melt channel (Fig. 3a) and melting in mantle plumes (Fig. 3b). Furthermore, the local degree of melting is indicated by shades. Both models have an initial crustal thickness of 30 km, representing crust formed during the earliest evolution, possibly from a magma ocean.
If melting takes place in a global layer, crustal thickness rapidly increases during thefirst 500 Myrof the evolution and90%of the crust is formed in this time period. Melting continues for another 500 Myr in this model, until major magmatic activity ceases around 1 Gyr. In this model, present-day melt production would be restricted to upwelling mantle plumes, preferably in a region underlying thickened crust like Tharsis or Elysium(Morschhauser et al., 2011).Maximummelt fractions in thismodel are around10%during thefirst few tens ofMyr, but quickly drop to 5% for the major part of the magmatically active phase. During the final phases of magmatic activity, melt fractions drop below 3%.
If melting in hot mantle plumes is considered the total amount of extractedmelt is considerably reduced for agiven time interval, as only a fraction fp of the melt that would be present in a global melt channel is available. The phase of crustal production extends to much larger times and low intensity magmatic activity is present up to 2.5 Gyr. A slightly smaller amount of melt is extracted before 500 Myr than in the global melt layer model, but both models result in the same present-day crustal thickness.Maximummelt fractions in the plumemodel are up to 40% during the early evolution while the core is still super-heated with respect to the mantle and the temperature difference across the lower thermal boundary layer is still large. Melt fractions then drop to 20% around 500 Myr, but are above 10% even at 1.5 Gyr until they drop below 5% at 2 Gyr.
For fixed crustal volumes, extraction of incompatible elements from the mantle is less efficient for larger melt fractions. Therefore, only 25% of heat producing elements (HPE) are extracted in the plume melting model. This corresponds to an enrichment comparable to mid ocean ridge basalts on the Earth, while in the global melt layer model 50% of the HPE are extracted. The longevity of major volcanic activity
in the plume melting model is a direct consequence of this inefficient removal of HPE from the mantle, but present-day melting is not precluded in both models. Magmatic activity would be restricted to regions of a thickened, thermally isolating crust (Schumacher and Breuer, 2006), and mantle plumes could penetrate into the stagnant lid (Kiefer and Li, 2009), thereby facilitating pressure-release melting. However, melt volumes associated with this late stage volcanism are expected to be small.
The amountof outgassedwater andCO2 for thesemodels is shown in Fig. 4, where the equivalent global layer thickness EGL and the outgassed CO2 pressure are shown as a function of time in panels a) and b), respectively. The EGL thickness corresponds to the total amount of water transported to the planetary surface and is a function of the magma water content. Therefore, the EGL thickness is larger if temperatures in the magma source regions are moderate, as small melt fractions will lead to a more efficient enrichment of water in the melt. The global melt layermodel results in an EGL of 61 m, 17 of which are outgassed after 500 Myr. The plume model outgasses only 17.5 m, 11 of which are outgassed after 500 Myr.
To calculate the amount of outgassed CO2, an oxygen fugacity corresponding to one log10 unit above the IW buffer has been assumed, but results are easily convertible to other oxidation states by noting that the CO2 pressure increases by one order of magnitude per increase of fugacity by one log10 unit. At IW+1, average concentration of CO2 in the melt are 1000 and 900 ppm for fp=1 and 0.01, respectively. Present-day CO2 pressures are similar for both models and reach 1 and 0.9 bar for fp=1 and 0.01, respectively. However,
timing of the outgassing is different and 85% of the outgassing occurs in the first 500 Myr for fp=1, whereas only 40% are outgassed for fp=0.01 in this time period. This difference in timing is of particular importance as atmospheric loss was probably strongest during the early phases of the planet's evolution when the EUV flux from the young sun was largest (Tian et al., 2009).
While most of the outgassing occurs in the first few hundred Myr, appreciable outgassing persists into the Noachian period and the integrated fluxes during the pre-Noachian (4.5–4.1 Gyr), Noachian (4.1–3.7 Gyr), Hesperian (3.7–2 Gyr), and Amazonian (2–0 Gyr) periods are given in Table 2. In the global melt layer and plume melting model 15.1 and 4.1 m of water are outgassed during the Noachian and CO2 pressures are increased by 246 and 240 mbar in this time-period. Although insufficient to generate greenhouse warming above the freezing point (Forget and Pierrehumbert, 1997), these pressures are sufficient to stabilize transient liquid water on the martian surface, which requires pressure in the range of 50 to 100 mbar (Richardson and Mischna, 2005). Alternatively, these pressures would suffice to stabilize brines (Fairén et al., 2009), which require pressures above the triple point only. Outgassing declines fast during the Hesperian in the global melt channel model, but is still significant in the plume melting model, where 364 mbar CO2 are outgassed. Outgassing in the Amazonian is found to be negligible.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion and conclusions
sections.text:
Using a thermo-chemical evolution model which reproduces the inferredmartian crust formationhistory,wehave calculated theamount of CO2 and H2O released to the martian atmosphere by volcanic outgassing. The amount of volatiles in the melt is limited by their respective solubilities and we treat water as an incompatible element using a fractional melting model when calculating water melt concentrations. Pressure and temperature in the magma source region affect the solubility of CO2 in themelt (Hirschmann andWithers, 2008) and our model allows for the calculation of outgassing rates in a selfconsistent manner. Outgassing rates are found to depend primarily on the outgassing efficiency, the bulk mantle water content, the mantle oxygen fugacity, and the local melt fraction.
We consider two end-member melting models which account for melting in a global melt layer as well as melting restricted to uprising mantle plumes. Although the use of any one of these models is probably unrealistic if applied in a strict sense, mantle conditions will likely be intermediate between these two end-member cases. In the global melt layermodel, large-scale crustal production ceases in the earlyHesperian, butmelting can be extended into the late Hesperian period in the plume melting model. This is primarily due to the inefficient extraction of heat producing elements in the plumemodel, which results in higher mantle temperatures. Note that both models allow for the formation of partial melt under present-day mantle conditions (Morschhauser et al., 2011),
provided that melting takes place in a region of locally thickened crust (Schumacher and Breuer, 2006) or inside the heads of uprising mantle plumes impinging on the lithospheric base (Kiefer and Li, 2009). However, melt volumes are expected to be minor during these late phases of volcanic activity.
Melt fractions in the martian mantle have been estimated from surface elemental abundances of Si, Fe, and Th, and results indicate that melt fractions associated with old volcanic provinces were larger than 10%,while late stage volcanism in Tharsis andElysium is associatedwith melt fractions below 10% (Baratoux et al., 2011). Therefore, although melt fractions up to 40% as estimated for the plume model are unrealistically large, a thermal state intermediate between global and plume melting model would be consistent with melt fractions N10% during the early evolution. Cooling of the planet would then slowly reduce melt fractions, until values b10% are achieved during the Amazonian period. Furthermore, cooling might be connected to a transition from a phase of globally distributed magmatism towards more localized activity, which could be associated with low-degree mantle convection (e.g., Roberts and Zhong, 2006).
At oxygen fugacities corresponding to one log10 unit above the iron– wustite buffer, average CO2 concentrations in the melt are around 0.1 wt.%, consistent with the values estimated by Hirschmann and Withers (2008), but considerably lower than concentrations in Hawaiian basalts, which have been widely used as a proxy for martian basalts (Craddock and Greeley, 2009;Manning et al., 2006; O'Neill et al., 2007; Phillips et al., 2001). Given that atmospheric pressure in the Hesperian and Amazonian is sensitive to the CO2 abundance in themelt (Manning et al., 2006), this difference is of particular importance. Assuming an initial bulk mantle water content of 100 ppm, water melt concentrations are 800 and 2500 ppm for the plume and global melt layer model, respectively.
Assuming relatively oxidizing mantle conditions and that the early martian atmosphere was lost by thermal escape (Tian et al., 2009), upper limits on the CO2 pressure during the Noachian period are ∼250 mbar, insufficient for appreciable greenhouse warming, which would require at least one bar of CO2 (Forget and Pierrehumbert, 1997; Kasting, 1991). This indicates that rather than being warm-and-wet (Jakosky and Phillips, 2001), martian surface temperatures were probably below freezing for the better part of the Noachian and the martian climate would be more appropriately described as being coldand-wet (Fairén, 2010; Gaidos and Marion, 2003).
Further support for the cold-and-wet hypothesis is provided by the analysis of 40Ar in ALH84001, which suggests that martian surface temperatures cannot have exceeded 273 K for substantial periods of time (Weiss et al., 2002). This does not preclude the possibility of temporarily elevated temperatures and short-lived sulfur volatiles could add to greenhouse warming by some 25 K during phases of major volcanic activity (Johnson et al., 2008). Togetherwithpressures in the 100 mbar range, this temperature increase would be sufficient to stabilize transient liquid water on the martian surface, as seems to be required by geological and mineralogical evidence. However, even without additional greenhouse warming, brines would still be liquid under inferred Noachian/Hesperian atmospheric conditions (Fairén et al., 2009; Möhlmann and Thomsen, 2011).
The small amount of volcanic outgassing derived here is also compatiblewith the lowpresent-day surface pressure of only 8 mbar, as atmospheric loss of CO2 appears to be relatively inefficient (Lammer et al., 2008) and only ∼150 mbar were lost to space by non-thermal escape since 3.8 Gyr (Johnson et al., 2000; Luhmann et al., 1992). Low escape rates also argue against significant impact delivery of volatiles, although theoretically this process can be quite efficient (Pham et al., 2009).
In contrast to the amount of outgassed CO2, which primarily depends on oxygen fugacity, the amount of outgassed water is sensitive to the assumedmeltingmodel and a total of 17.5 and 61 m of water (equivalent global layer, EGL) are delivered to the surface in the
plume and global melt layer model, respectively, if an initial bulk water content of 100 ppm is assumed. This difference is caused by the sensitivity of magma water content on melt fraction, which differs significantly for these two models. In total, volcanic outgassing is found to remove 10% to 50% of water from the mantle for the plume and global melt layer model, respectively.
Geological evidence suggests that water volumes required for the formation of martian outflow channels are ∼500 m EGL (Carr, 1996) at the time of peak outflow activity (∼3 Ga). The volume of a putative ocean in the northern lowlands, which is poorly constrained with respect to its timing, is estimated to amount to 100–550 m EGL (Di Achille and Hynek, 2010; Head et al., 1999). These volumes are significantly larger than the amount of water outgassed from the interior if a bulk mantle water content of 100 ppm is assumed. In order to outgas enough water to account for a 500 m EGL, bulk mantle water content would need to be of the order of 0.1 wt.%, 25 times larger than predicted by models of the martian bulk composition (Wänke and Dreibus, 1994). It therefore seems unlikely that outgassing of H2O significantly contributed to the martian hydrological cycle.
One possible source for the missing water could be ice stored in the subsurface, which could have been activated by impacts (Segura et al., 2002) or intrusivemagmatic activity (see, e.g., Rodriguez et al., 2005 and references therein).Water releasedduring large impacts couldhavealso liberated enoughwater to create transientwet andwarm conditions on the surface (Segura et al., 2002; Toon et al., 2010), but the size of the subsurface water reservoir remains poorly constrained (Clifford et al., 2010).
